Needs Review

John V. LeMoyne
Melvale, Station "L"
Baltimore, MD.
Sep. 23. 1904
My dear Dula?.
I trust the children are all right
again. Do Madeleine and Romaine? bath have to go to school
alone.? You had better keep the "urigher?" as home.
She ought to be irisenicted? by her old Grand-dad.
I sent those potatoes off. + endorse RR. receipt
showing freight paid. Mr Peisset. I suspect, would not
want to trust a "Chicago swell" for the freight. In using
the potatoes, use the "Early rose" first. these are darked in
color of skin than the Burbank. If you want
Cosette, why dont you send you send for her + done with it. Take her
+ Daisy too if you like, but take them now. Val is
driving? C. + your trap every day to the club. he is 
playing golf every day alone. He says he is practising.
Madeleine is struggling with the servant question.
He have had quite a variety. yesterday she sent off one
Irish girl. that did not appear to have common sense
+ got Mary Treneau?, to-day she has some other
woman + unclear unclear who she will have tomorrow
I was sorry to hear of her Scotts death. You
do not say if you found camping the brut? very
troublesome. I hope William feels all right again
With a very warm greeting to you all
Dad.
We have had two cool frosty nights but I do not think the tomatoes
are hurt.
Completed

John V. LeMoyne
Melvale, Station "L"
Baltimore, MD.
July 11th 1904
My dear little duck. aint you glad the
4th is safely past? I am. I am in favor of
abolishing fire works altogether. there should be
some better way of celebrating. Have you seen the
list of accidents? Killed and wounded + so many of them
children If I had the ordering of it I should have
it rain all day + night of the 4th My advice to you 
is. when there is to be fire works. go some where else
I was amused at your experience with
the cook. The club was all right, but the pepper
pot. no! no! Never throw pepper, that would be
awful mean. As you say nothing
about your garden I am afraid it is not doing well
We are having too much rain but the garden is
doing well + a lot of vegetables going to waste.  Ann
gives me peas twice a day. the best thing from the
garden, so far, is the dewberries. although I have
only two bushes bearing. I have been eating them
for about a week + we had a nice dish for dinner
yesterday - they are lavase? + softer than blackberries
As Romaine? says, beat blackberry altogether, The +
C Ellicote are bound to plant some. Mr & Mrs
McL. + Mr C Ellicote took dinner with me yesterday
Was Will defending the 40- men. or
Needs Review

suing? for them? I am glad he is to give up night
work - I think he will find, if he does not get, each
day, as much as he wants, or expects in the morning
to do - He will do just as well in the long run.
Your aunt Jane writes very
unfavorable account of Nan.
I am only getting on soso - the
last two days my right knee has troubled me more
than heretofore. I am expecting Dr Fulcher out to see
me in a day or two. he has had a letter from
Dr Goldthwait? who advises some delay in my
going to Boston - But I have been a long time
now, fooling with these doctors. have I not?
Tell the children I miss them
very much + my little wriggler. I wish I had her
on my lap. Good bye. you devoted Dad
Needs Review

1
On the night of the fire, as I was going to bed
I noticed a fire in the city, but paid no attention to it. But awoke
about three O.C. in the morning and there was a great light
shining in my window. I immediately ordered my horse +
drove to town. I got only as far South as Superior St. It 
was still quite dark, except the fire light and the wind blowing a
gale in going east on Superior St. my horse stopped and on
getting out I found I was among the timbers +c of the steeple
of the Catholic Cathedral which had been blown off before any
fire had reached it. There was no fire then in the immediate
neighborhood. thought I believe some buildings father north
were burning I went to Mrs Roberts house, found it
open but deserted, I went on to Mr Tiemans?, they had all
gone except John Stockton, who was trying to save some
small things. I found Mrs Stokes and Miss Sally, not
knowing what to do or where to go. Gail .S. + his son had
gone north carrying their silver. I put Mrs Stoked + MIss
Sally in my gig, and also an old family portrait, they were
anxious to save _ taking the horse by the head we went to
Chicago Av., there the fire was all around us. we went west as
fast as I could run, to Clearborn? St. and thence north. Above
Walton place I found Mr Tieman. I took out the portrait (which
we afterwards saved) + put him in and told him to drive home +
send my cart back + to tell the boys to put the carriage horses
in the hunting wagon + to come down quickly, which was done
+ we spent the forenoon moving furniture +c to Lincoln Park
Needs Review

2
where they were all burned up. except one load we sent up
for Mr Hosmer which he managed to save I was in
the neighborhood of Washington Park all morning and saw how
the Mahlon Ogden house was saved. When the fire reached
the houses on the South side of the park, the wind was
blowing hard from the west and I saw this row of houses go
down, as if tinder, and it looked as if the fire might sweep
eastward the Lake and be checked on the North. Dr Collier
was busy around his church hoping it might escape, but
directly after this row of houses was down the wind shifted to
the South + the flames swept up on each side of the Ogden
house and we had to move north.
Mr Houghtelling. on east side of Dearborn, was burying
his silver in his back yard his hat blew off and he called to
his neighbor "Dole I wish you would bring me that hat."
"Go to thunder with your old hat." "Jim Dole you are
not worth a cent at a fire"
The procession was moving North, as I went up
Dearborn St with my cart loaded I passed Mr Perry Smith +
Mr Parsons. walking in the middle of the street, Mr Smith
had a bottle of champaign in his hand. which he said
was all that was saved from Dunlaps cellar. I asked if I
could do any thing for them they said no. they were all
right But Mr S. said I must take the champaign + he
put it in my cart. (-We drank that bottle together many year later-)
As I went thro the Park I saw a young girl
Needs Review

3.
sitting on a matrass near the Lake. She was quite
alone and had nothing, but a bird cage with a canary
I found she was stranded and did not what to do. So I
took her home cage + all + the next day got her to
her friends When I got home I found the lawn
covered with furniture, pictures +c. and the house full
of people There was a good representation of the 
North side Messrs. Sam. Barrett. Lavabee. Houghletting
Julian Ramsey. Thos? Phillips. Genl. Stokes +c +c.
While we were getting something to eat, neighbor
Bauman ruched in, with an axe in his hand, and
said I must cut down all the trees about the house. he
was about to chop down his. I remonstrated. I thought
the trees not so liable to catch fire standinf as they would
be lying in a heap. So we concluded to spare the trees, though
at that time I was not sure there was anything which
would not burn, and the sparks and burning branches were
flying over us. So we got out on the roofs. Mr Larabee.
Same Marnett; all our boys + some of our little girls with
broom and buckets of water and we worked away brushing the sparks
off. +c. When at work, some one came up and told me
me that some of the people below were getting frightened, sure
the house would burn +c. So I went down + tried to encourage
them. I told them I thought we could save the house +c +c.
I had two large wagons hitched up and brought to the front door
+ told them the wagons should stay there, if the house caught
Needs Review

4
fire the wagons would hold the women _ they could drive
where they liked. I went to the roof again, [some of
the timid ones did leave] and we worked there hard
until about ten or eleven O.C. that night, when it began
to rain and we all came down, and going into the
dining room we found the remains of supper and Mr
San Barrett + I discovered that cold boiled potatoes
with salt were mighty good. Your Mother
was in Pittsburg + Sue Fahnestork was managing the
house. The rooms were full of beds all occupied, and 
there was a long row of beds side by side in the music
room. Some not yet taken. We were told that some
robbers were going about taking what they wanted. So we 
got a gun or two ready, and then as our unclear struggle with
this awful calamity was done, we went to bed
Completed

Charlie has only finished one ring
He will sent Petites another time --written upside down on top of page
Home Nov. 30. 1863.
Dearest John,
I have been intending
ever since I got home, more than
a week ago, to write you a long
letter, but I have not really
felt settled until now, and I
have been busy in many ways,
seeing, and being seen. And
for three or four days I have been
stupid with a bad cold, the
worst one I have had since I
went away from here last
winter.
On the whole, I find
things here pretty much as I left
them, certainly not improved
any, and in some respects
rather worse. Ma has been
Completed

very well, ever since her visit
to Chicago, until within the
last few days. She thinks
her stomach is not of order, and
I think the sudden change in
the weather has given her a 
little cold. and she is nervous
about the fighting in Virginia.
I think she will be better
in a few days. She certainly
has not hurt herself by living
too richly, for Pa is getting
too economical to provide even
the necessaries. He won't pay
2nbicts. for butter. nor 15 for
eggs. He will not even
buy hay for his horse and
cow, says they much "do
without." I wonder where
his economy will end. I
presume like Tommy Jones, in
Completed

shavings and green spectacles?
Charlotte is in Pittsburgh,
having her teeth pieced, for about
the fiftieth time. She will be
gone about two weeks longer, and
will be at home only a week or
so before going to Washington. She
wants to leave Granny with us
again! Although Romaine told
her how much trouble and care
it made for Ma last winter. I 
did not have an opportunity to talk
to her about it, as she left a 
day or two after I got home, but
I have written my sentiments on
the matter quite plainly. I
suppose she will be angry, but
I do not think it right, neither
Ma nor Sis is pleased with the
prospect, but they won't say
anything, because Charlotte is so
Completed

good and kind in many ways.
I cannot bear to do it either,
and she will think is is pure
selfishness in my part, but I
did it from a sense of duty.
I don't think Granny is so bad
as she used to be, but she is
restless - and fussy - and very
troublesome. I really think
the children here are improving
a little! except Sophie, who is
very pert, forward and wilful.
You would have laughed to
hear Romaine's account of her
sickness in Pittsburgh, and their
vain attempt to put medecine
down her throat. They had to
shut all the doors and windows
to prevent an alarm in the 
neighborhood. But it
makes me feel badly to see
Completed

of farming for himself, and is
determined, he says, to have the best
farm in the county.. I am glad
his prospect are so good. He
has more taste for farming than
for anything else, and has no
capital to enter any kind of
business. He has 150 very
choice sheep, his two horses
and a cow! besides some money
made by his trip West. I don't 
know how much. A great
many sheep they put out on
the shares, he thinks on very 
good terms. They receive 3
pounds of wool a year from
each sheep - for three years -
and then get young sheep
back in place of the ones
they give now. Mr. Kuhn
told Annie lately that she need
Completed

feel no uneasiness about Julius's
prospects, that he intended to
see him started in life, just
the same as his own son. But
Julius wants to stock his farm
without any assistance, and
would like to sell his house -
which Charlotte wants to buy -
but Mr. Mills thinks 3,000 is
too much. I think it is too,
Hayes only asks 3,300 for his
new house. Well, I did
not mean to take up so much
of my letter with Julius's business
But I suppose you are
interested in that.
There is something else I want
to write about, and that it,
my teeth. I see Pa does not
mean to take any interest in
responsibility in the matter. He
Completed

stops any allusion to the matter 
by, "Very well, I don't care!" He
wants me to understand that I acted 
on my own responsibility, that being
"of age", I did as I pleased.
But I can't bear to have you
pay the bill, not that I am
unwilling to incur the obligation
to you, I have no such feeling
toward you, feeling that I do in
some sort, belong to you. And
indeed there is hardly another
member of the family from whom
I could receive so much. But
I don't think you can afford to
make presents to sets of teeth! and
I don't like to have you spend so
much on me. It is taking the
place of both brother and father.
I often wonder whether any one
else has such good brothers as I.
I can't tell you what comfort
I take in my teeth, they seem
to fit perfectly, and I am not
Completed

Charlie, so pale and delicate, and
to see hoe he eats. I watched
him on Thanksgiving, eating oysters
turkey, stuffing and gravy ad lib,
cabbage, vinegar, musstard, +c.
and finishing with double portions
of mince and pumpkin pies, so
it any wonder he is sick?
Julius seems to have been
struck with the contrast between
your children and these. I
suppose he intends to train up
his daughter in the way she should
go. Don't it seem funny for Dude
to be a father! Annie has been
very ill, but is better now, and
they hope out of danger. Her
baby weighed ten pounds, and
Julius thinks it looks very much
like Annie. He is very
much pleased at the prospect of
Completed

conscious of their being in my
mouth. Every one tells me
I am looking well, which I
suppose is partly attributable to
the teeth.
Did you think Ma
and Sis had a cool way of 
receiving presents? Ma sat down
to write purposely to tell you how
much she liked her muff, and
forgot it until the letter was 
gone. Sis did not get her box
of diamonds until this evening.
I had to leave my trunk in 
Pittsburgh, when I went down
the river, and left it open
for Romaine to put from things
in. She could not get all the
things in, so took out some
things, and among others my
Completed

work basket, containing sis's box,
Willie's knife, and other little
things, Sis is greatly pleased
but I think she means to
tell you so herself.
Charlie has been making rings
for the little girls, present them
with his love, and tell Bud
he liked the ducks very much.
Sophie made a great fuss over the
pictures of her "dear little cousins."
Kiss all the darlings for me,
I miss them very much.
Mary Bureau wants a picture
of the boys, and Julius wants
them all, there was none for 
him, You must not forget 
that you are to send me one 
of your own, Tell Jule I 
expect a letter from her soon,
With much love,
Jane.
Completed

John V. LeMoyne
Chicago
Ill.
Completed

Home Wednesday evening.
Dearest John,
Can't you come and spend
Christmas with us? Frank is at
home, very unexpectedly to us, on a 
fifteen days' furlough. Romaine hopes
to be over, and we are writing
to Julius to come. Won't you come
too and make the family circle
complete once more? I do wish
you could, we would all be so
happy. Charlotte will be home
in a few days and expects to go
back with Frank. on the 28th.
I received your letter today, but
have not time to answer it this
evening. We had not a 
suspicion that Frank was coming
until the stage drove up to the
door today. We are all well
and all send much love.
Tell dear Franky that I was
Completed

delighted to get his note, and
will write to him soon, We
are not making very extensive
preparations for Christmas. But
would it not be nice to be all
at home again?
Yours hastily & aff-
Jane.
Completed

John v. LeMoyne
Chicago
Ill.
[[Writing down right side of envelope--
Jane
Reed unclear 18. 1864
Completed

Home Friday. Jan 15.
Dearest John,
Ma wants me to write
to enquire if you are all frozen up?
She has been very anxious about
you ever since that very cold
weather began, and thinks
nothing but the fact that you
are all frozen will account for
your long silence. We have been
looking for a letter for a week
and in the meantime, Ma has
been reading all the newspaper
accounts of the severe weather, out
West. We did not quite equal
you, but for us it was very
cold. One night it was 12
degrees below zero, and several
times was six and eight below.
Ma says she learned to consider
Completed

it the height of happiness to sit
still by the fire, with her feet
on the fender, and have nothing
to do. In the midst of
the cold last week Pa and Julius
went off to Columbus to attend
a wool. growers conventions, I was
astonished that Pa did actually
go, but he did, and was
gone from Tuesday morning until
Friday night, and seemed to
enjoy it, too. Ma hopes he
will be for going all the time!
Julius has been here most
of this week, buying stock, or
rather implements for farming.
He and Annie expect to come
here in Feb. and stay in Charlotte's
house for awhile. Charlotte
has bought the house at 2588
and Mr. Harding has bought
Hayes's at 3560. They will
go into it just as it is, as
Completed

Mr. H. can't afford any alterations
yet. Romaine wrote to
us yesterday that she had just seen
Dr. King, who told her he had
sent Frank a commission as
Surgeon, but I don't know
whether he will have to change
his reg't or not.
Charlotte seems quite comfortable
in Washington. She boards in the
same house that Mr. Mill's?' office 
is in.
Now I think I have told
you all the news, and as I
am in a hurry I will bid you
all an affectionate adieu.
Much love to Jule, and all the
children,
Yours very aff-
Jane,
I am going to send you a town
paper with the deaths of the past
year in it
Completed

[[Written on left side of envelope--
Jane
Real? July 3/64]]
John V. LeMoyne -
Chicago
Ill.
Completed

Home Friday - 
Dear John,
We are sending you, by
express, a little box, with some
things that Nannie and Sis
had ready to send for Christmas,
but by some mistake they did
not get to Pittsburgh in time for
Mrs. Murrays box. Nannie did
not think them worth sending,
but Ma thought they would
please the children.
Your letter and Franky's came
a few days ago, more than
a week after they were written.
I suppose you have had one
from me, in the meantime.
We are all as usual,
Frank was appointed Surgeon
to the 13th Penn. Cavalry, but
Gen. Sykes refuses to let him
Completed

leave his present position. He
wants him made Surg. to the 
9th. I don't know how it will
be fixed. We will hear again
soon. Don't be so long
about writing again. Ma
was really quite uneasy about
you.
Yours hastily & aff-
Jane.
Completed

[[Written down left side of envelope--
Jane
Read april 23/64]]
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago
Ill.
Completed

Home April 18, 1864
Dearest John,
If you don't answer
letters, of course you don't expect to
get them. But perhaps you
have forgotten that you owe Ma
a letter, so I'll just take time
to refresh your memory. Ma
says to tell you that she has been
intending to write every day for a
week, but has felt too worthless.
She had been very unwell for
several weeks, and I begin to
feel very anxious about her.
She has one cold after another, and
is very weak. She has not been
out for three or four weeks except
to Nannie's or Charlotte's. For one
thing, the weather has been very
bad, and that has helped to keep
Completed

her shut up. But I have hardly
ever seen her so weak as she is 
now. She says she is worn out.
I hope as the weather gets 
warmer, if it ever does, that she
will be better, especially when she
gets something green to eat.
I have been thinking lately
how nice it would be if you
would come and stay a week or
two with her, and bring some of
the children. I know it would
do her good. Charlotte has
just bought Mrs. Marshell's horse
and carriage, and she expects Ma
to ride a great deal in that. The 
horse is a quiet old thing that
any one can drive. Charlotte
has been at home for nearly two
weeks, but is very weak, and
not able to go about much. She came with Pa, on his return 
from Washington City.
Completed

Julius and Annie are very
comfortably settled in their new
home, and seem very happy.
Annie is charming, and has
plenty of milk and cream and
fresh eggs, in real country style.
Their baby bids fair to rival
your Julie in size. Rose is four
months old and weighs 18 pounds.
She is a very bright cunning little
thing, and a great pet with us
all. Nannie has not moved
yet. Her house needed some repairs
and the weather has been so bad.
Today she was at our house, the
first time she has been out.
She has not named the baby yet,
but I think it will be Annie.
I suppose it will improve, but
it is no beauty now.
I believe Mary Acheson and Belle
Todd have both been married since
Ma wrote to you. The girls are
Completed

[[Written on left side of envelope --
Jane
Read June 29/64]]
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago
Ill.
Completed

Home. June 14, 1864.
Dear John,
It is a long time since we
have heard anything from you. I think
your bad habits grew on you, as you
grew - younger! I suppose you
know that Ma is in Pittsburgh, though
it is hardly safe to presume so, as she
has been so disinclined to letter
writing since she has been there, that
I doubt if she has even written to Frank.
She thinks herself a little better
within a few days past, but is very
weak. I have never seen her so feeble
as she is this Spring. She thought
a little of going to Chicago, but gave
it up because she did not feel able
to take so long a ride. Even the
ride to Altona, which she took by
way of experiment tired her very much.
She depends on your coming home
Completed

this summer, with all, or part of
the family, and you must not
disappoint her. I cannot shut out
the fear that we will not have our
mother with us very much longer.
I wish you could all come. It
is so long since we have had you
here, and there have been so many
changes in the family. You must
not let yourself be such a stranger to
your brothers and sisters. Come,
and bring all, or if they won't
all come, bring as many as you
can, and be sure that Franky is
one. He is Ma's darling of all her
grand-children, much as she loves them
all, though it would not do to say so
to every body.
But I am forgetting that
this is a business letter. I want
your opinion professionally, on stocks,
investments, &?. Pa has astonished
me by himself proposing to hand over
Completed

my money to me, saying that he
has no use for it. I believe he is
not putting out much money now, and
as he is not making any thing out
of it he don't want the bother of it.
And then, I can't help seeing some
connection between this and his telling
Mr. Harding in the winter that he would 
not pay any more bills for us. I think
so from his saying yesterday something
about my "doing better with it," in
other hands. Of course I am
not sorry to get it out of his hands
even if nothing more can be made by
it, for it is anything but agreeable
to get the interest from him. What
shall I do with it? Of course I 
don't want to risk it in any way,
but if it can be made to bring in
more than six per cent I shall be
very glad, as 42 dollars a year is
not a very large income.
I suppose he will be for throwing
Completed

up Sis's money too, as she is of age
now. Pa suggested that perhaps
Mr. Harding could use it, but I
am afraid of dry goods. So please
give me your opinion.
We have not heard from Frank
for more than a week, and will
not I suppose very soon, as I see
Sheridan is out again. Those cavalry
men have hard times - Frank said
that when they were out on that first
raid after Grant moved, he was from
the 29th of April, until the 25th of May
without getting his under clothes washed
except once, and then he had to put
them on again wet. It would be
dreadful to him, he is as fussy about
washing and changing as you are.
Sandie Acheson is home with a 
bad wound in his face, the cheek bone
is broken, and the Dr.s tell him it will
be some time before all the fragments of

bone work out and allow the face to

heal. Jake Shagle was wounded pretty
Completed

much in the same way. A good many
from this county were killed and wounded
but I don't know whether you know them.
A brother from Huston Paul's was killed,
and two young McCullough's from near
Wotrings?. Mrs. Humphrey was
buried yesterday. She died of disease
of the heart. Old Mr. Denounandie?
died on the same day, very suddenly.
Poor Mr. Shagle has become
entirely blind, and has gone to
Philadelphia to have an operation
performed. If it is successful he
will come back here. If not he will
go to live with his children in Iowa,
as Mrs. Eckert is not able to take care
of him.
We are having strawberries,
though it is not a very good year for
them. Julius had peas a week
ago. He has some very early kind.
He will not have them for several
Completed

weeks yet. Things look promising
for the farmer, and Julius is in very
good spirits. Annie was quite
sick for two or three weeks but is
better again. Charlotte thinks
she is a little better, but she still
has to lie down a great part of the
day. Nannie is very well, and has
quite a fine large baby, whom she 
calls Annie Romaine. The name was
not her choice. Ma gave it tho Annie
and Mr. Harding put Romaine to it.
Little Rose is the darling, such a fat
round cunning little thing.
Tell Franky I have not been able to
make his collection of wild flowers. Today
is the first time I have felt strong
enough to walk to the woods, and now
the flowers are gone. Next year maybe
I'll succeed better. Give much 
love to all, with a good hug all
around. Yours very aff, Jane.
Love to Carrie. What is she
doing this summer?
Completed

[[Written on left side of the envelope--
Jane
Read July 4 1864]]
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago.
Ill.
Completed

Home. Thursday afternoon.
Dear John. 
Your letter is just received,
you see I am prompt. In the 
first place I did not sooner tell
you Ma thought of going to Chicago
because I did not know it. She 
had no such intention when she left
home. She only expected to stay
a week or ten days, but has prolonged
her stay from time to time. We look
for them home this evening. Ma
says she is better now than when
she went over. Now, for your
other questions. Romaine and
family expect to come over about
the middle of July, but I don't
think you need be afraid of
encountering Nicholas disagreeably, he
spends most of his time out at
Julius's, and I know, has no
Completed

more wish to enjoy your society, than
you have for his. And I know
Romaine would like so much to
see you. As to the children,
don't come without them. I think
we can easily keep them out of
harms way. I will promise to
do everything in my power towards 
it. And what I cannot do, Ma 
and Sis, and you can do. You
need not be afraid, I think. In
some respects, you will find the
children here improved. Fannie
especially, is a right nice child,
something of a tomboy, but much
more tractable than she used to be.
Willie is improving too. So bring
them all. I can't tell you 
how much I want to see them,
and I promise to devote myself to
them.
The cars leave Wheeling
about half past three in the
Completed

afternoon, not being as punctual
as some other railroads. They often
wait a little while from passengers.
There is also a hack, which
comes over from Pittsburgh on
Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday,
starting at ten o'clock in the
morning, and reaching here about
five in the afternoon, returning
to Pittsburgh in the alternate days,
but leaving here at seven in the
morning, arriving there at one.
Now I -am- think I have
answered all the questions, I have
not taken time to tell you how glad
I am that you are coming, I can't!
We had a hurried note from
Frank a few days ago, on their
return from their last raid. He
said they would be forced to rest
a while, as their horses were entirely
worn out. So must the men
have been, though he did not say so
Completed

I am afraid I cannot get the
piano tuned, there was a tuner
here this morning, but Pa would
not get it done.
Now I must stop, I will
add a line, to tell you if Ma
comes. With much love to all,
Janey,
Ma has arrived, not very
tired, and looking much
better than when she left.
Completed

[[Written on left side of the envelope--
Jane
Read Aug 20 1864]]
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago
Ill.
Completed

Home. Friday. July 29./64
Dearest John.
We received today, yours
or Jule's letter, which we have been
expecting for several days. I
intended writing any how, but
for one thing I have not had time,
and then until within a few
days I could not write anything
favorable, and I did not want
to write anything bad. Ma and
Mr. Harding have both been worse
since you left then before, but
are both better now. The day
you left, and the next day were
about the worst days Ma has had.
Her cough was so violent and her
fever so high that we felt very
anxious about her. Pa tried two
or three things before he succeeded
in soothing her cough, and even
Completed

then did not relieve the pain and
oppression. But one night last
week, I think Wednesday, the
irritation seemed suddenly to change
to the outside of her breast, and
in the morning there was an
eruption out, like scarlet fever,
just where the pain and irritation
had been. Since then she has
been very much relieved, and
her cough is gradually leaving her.
She is very weak, and suffers
very much from the heat, but
her appetite is improving, and for
two or three days she has resumed
her rides, so I hope she will
soon regain her strength.
Mr. Harding has gone through
a curse of fever, and for some
days was very ill. Even Pa
spoke as if the issue was doubtful.
I don't know what kind
of fever it was, Pa just said
Needs Review

fever, with diseased stomach. We
talked of having him brought over
here, he was so much disturbed
by the noise on the street, and
their rooms were so small and so
warm, but we thought Ma's
cough would be as bad as the
noise on the street. And after
a day or two, his fever took a turn
and he did not mind it so much.
For several days now he has been
sitting up, and yesterday took a 
ride. Today he is tottering around
with a cane, and has been over
here. So I think both our
invalids are convalescent now.
We had several minor cases in
the meantime. Sis was on her
back all last week, the children
have had chicken .pox. and Nan
was sick yesterday, in bed nearly
all day. I think from fatigue.
I have been the only able. bodied
Needs Review

woman of the establishment, and
I begun to feel rather used up,
but a little rest will put me right
again. We have had several
letters from Frank lately. When he 
last wrote they were in camp on the
James river near Light.house point,
the first time they have been in a 
comfortable camp this summer. They
had been doing picket duty in the
read of the army for a little while,
but had returned to the river. Frank
is not very well. He says his legs are
covered with sores, between boils and
hives, caused by riding so much in
the heat and dust. Of course riding
is very painful, and on their return
from Petersburg he was obliged to
confiscate a rebel buggy, and hitch
his horse to it. I hope a little
rest, and better diet will cure him.
We had quite an alarm
the other day on Julius's account.
A man came galloping into town
Needs Review

to say that his hay was on fire, and
get men to help extinguish it. We
thought at first it was near the
house. A great cloud of smoke
was visible, but when we got 
out there he found it was one
of the meadows near Will. Workman's.
The hay was cut, but not caked?
up, and the men had found a 
hornet's nest, which they tried to
burn, and as everything was very
dry, of course it spread very fast.
Julius was off on the other side
of the farm at his oats, and before
help came about an acre of the 
hay was burned. It was near
the fences, and near a large stack,
so we were very thankful it was
no worse. The men beat it out
with green branches and reeds.
I don't know how Julius
would feel about parting with the
tea-pot, but I don't think Ma
Needs Review

would like his doing it. She wants
each of the boys to have at least
one piece of the old silver. I will
see what Dude thinks, but I think
he will want to keep it.
Romaine is going into Pa's house to
lodge during the remainder of her 
stay. She thinks the children are
improving in health here, and will
stay for some weeks yet, but as
they are too many for any one house
she will put some beds chairs +c
in that house and stay there.
We are sorry to hear of your
sickness, and hope you are better
long ago. I have no recollection of
the occasion you allude to, and
am sure I could never have done
so heartless a thing as to laugh at
any one's suffering.
Give much love to Jule, and all
the dear children. I will not
pronounce between Julie and Rose
until I see them together.
Yours aff, Jane.
Needs Review

[[Written down the left side of the envelope--
Jane
Recd Sept 16/64]]
John V. LeMoyne.
Chicago.
Ill.
Needs Review

Wednesday evening
Dearest John,
I should have answered
your letter sooner, if Ma had not just
written. I suppose her letter passed
yours on the road. We were very
gald to hear from you, it had been a
long time since your last letter came.
We are all just now, in a tolerable
state of health, but I believe it is the
first time I could say that, since you
were here. We have had one or two
sick, nearly all the time. Ma begins
to seem like herself again, and goes
around a good deal, but she has not
yet walked as far as Julius's.
Mr. Harding cannot walk without
a cane yet, but in other respects is
pretty well. Romaine and family
are still here, also old Mrs. Wade.
They all expect to return to Pittsburgh
Needs Review

together next Saturday. Nicholas
talks of buying that brick house near
Julius's, and fixing it up for a summer
residence. They are too many now to
make such long visits, at least
Charlotte thinks so.
I had a letter from Frank today.
He is still in charge of their Division
Hospital, though he is well enough now
to rejoin his regiment and is very
anxious to do so. He says he has not
seen anything of Joe Stockton. Did
you direct Joe to the Hospital, or the
16th red't? Frank has not been with
his reg't for nearly two months. His
hospital steward, Sam Potter died not
long ago. I suppose Ma told you of
it, and of Fred Barlow's death.
John Acheson was wounded not long
ago, in the fighting near Atlanta, but
not seriously. He thinks Ab. Baird?
is a great general. Sandie Acheson
has been quite ill in hospital, and
Needs Review

Joe, who was one of the hundred dago? men
came home last week, very sick with
fever. Isn't it hard to have three boys
suffering at once?
We are all busy baking and cooking
this week. It is the "Fair Week," and
the laddies of the Christian commission are
going to provide dinner, on the grounds
for all who will buy. I made 34
pies this morning, of pumpkin and
custard, and Ma made 200 ginger
cakes. We are waiting for
further particulars of Sheridan's fight,
Annie's father-in-law is in it, and
George Caldwell, Tom McReunars? would
have been, only that he was lately detailed
to attend on one of their wounded officers.
Mrs. Lacock thinks she can 
dry the apples for you, not just now,
but in a few weeks when the flies
are less annoying. She promises choice
fall apples, and wants to know if
you don't want some nice apple butter.
Needs Review

Apples are very abundant and very
good this year. We have a great many
on the farm, and plenty of wine apples
at home. I wish the children had some
of them. Our grapes are just
beginning. We picked about half a 
bushel off the vine running over the
apple tree over the spring house, and
Julius says there is a bushel more on it.
Mary Burean has a daughter, which
she calls for Ma, Madeline Burean,
a nice large baby.
I must send this to the office
in a hurry, so with love to all.
Yours aff,
Jane.
Needs Review

[[Written along left side of envelope--
Jane
Recd Oct 26/64]]
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago.
Ill.
Needs Review

Home. Oct. 21, 1864.
Dearest John,
I am all alone this
evening, as the rest of the family are
at Charlotte's, celebrating Mr. Wills's birthday.
I did not go over for tea, as I
thought the table would be full without
me, and it has given me a quiet
time to answer your letter. I don't
know when Ma will find time to
write, she can do nothing these bright
days but go to the woods, and gather
colored leaves. She does not seem
to feel fatigued after her walks, but
she still coughs a little, and suffers
sometimes with the old pain in her
side. The rest of us are as
usual. Next week we are
Needs Review

going to make apple butter, after
the old fashion, on the wood fireplace
in the cellar. Won't you come
and help us? Pa has taken a
sudden fancy for it, is having some
extra sweet cider made, and we are
to use nine apples to stir in. If it
is good I'll send you a can or two.
I have not been able to see Mrs.
Lacock again. I suppose she could
send some in a small keg. How
much could you use. Jane Potter
has been making apple molasses, which
I think is a great deal better than
apple butter. Julius has
been busy for several days picking
the apples on the farm, on the shares.
We will have a good many, and
they seem very sound, though not
Needs Review

very large. I thought they were
abundant every where.
We had letters from Frank today.
His regiment are doing picket duty
near Petersburg now, and are on
picket half the time. He does not
expect to be home until they go into
winter quarters, he will not ask for
a furlough until then. He has not
been home since last Christmas. It is
a long time, but I hope it will not
do him any harm. We do what we
can to make it up to him by writing
very often, and the home ties do not
seem to grow weak with him. A few
days ago he sent Ma 350 dollars, asking
her to invest it and use the interest
to pay her pew rent. He is constantly
sending something to Julius, Sis and me.
Needs Review

I don't think he keeps any more of his
pay than meets his necessary expenses.
We hear, now and then, indirectly, accounts
of him that make us feel very proud
of our boy. Not long ago his name
was sent in as a candidate for appointment
as Brigade Surg. and he only missed it
because he was the very youngest Surg.
in the Div. both in years and date of
commission. He knew nothing of it
until afterward.
Julius was not drafter. He is enrolled
in the borough, and they raised
enough bounty money to fill up their
quota. In Greene county there was
so much disturbance about it, that
several companies of soldiers were sent
there to preserve the peace.
In this county the Union ticket was
Needs Review

elected by a majority of 150! In the
borough the Democrats carried the election
by 60.
John McRenman? was married 
last week, to Miss Kate Arnett, of
Philadelphia, a niece of Mary Woodward's,
and said to be a very pretty bright
girl. She has been living with
William Woodward for sometime. They
are traveling now, but are to be here
in a few weeks, have a reception at
the Dr's +c. Anne and Belle went
on with him. I believe he has
bought back his old business on Federal
St. Allegheny.
Do you know that our
College and Jefferson have united? The
regular College course, that is, Sophomore
Junior + Senior classes, are to be in
Needs Review

Canonsburgh?. The Preparatory dept. and
Freshman class here, with a Scientific
and Mathematical dept, Modern languages,
and an Agricultural school, if they can
get a grant of land form the legislature.
There is to be one board of trustees, and
one endowment fund. Dr. Beattie of
Stenbeuville? has given them fifty thousand
dollars, and a Mrs. Brown? twenty-five thousand.
It is to be called "Washington + Jefferson."
The people here generally seem satisfied
with the arrangement.
Little Rose is trying hard to talk, she
can say, Mama, pretty, + a few such
little words, and is as sweet and good
as ever. Nannie's baby improves in
appearance, and is very bright.
Tell the children I wish they could
have Aunt Jane and Christmas both.
My heart is with you, if my bodily
presence is not. I find no other family
of children that I would like to live with.
Much love to Jule, and all the darlings.
Yours aff, Jane.
Needs Review

[[Written along left side of envelope--
Jane
Received Nov 19 1864]]
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago
Ill.
Needs Review

Dearest John,
See how prompt I am, 
your letter only came today. It cam
in company with one from Frank and
one from Sis, who is in Pittsburg.
I guess she will think it is a
grand thing to be twenty-one, and have
Pa say "I don't care, you can do as
you please" when she wants to go
away. Frank's letter announces
his promotion to the rank of Brigade
surgeon, 2nd brig. 2nd Cavalry Div.
It is quite flattering, for so young
a man, coming unsought, and to
one who has no "friends with influence.
At their last fight near Boynot?
[[Written on left side--
I am very glad to hear that Mrs. Tiernan? has a son.
Congratulate her for
me. Had?. Blackstock
has returned
from Minnesota
engaged to some one
there, and in
Spring they are
all going not to
live there. Mrs.
Boone came with
her, but is going
back. thinks
she cannot live
in this climate.
Give my love to
all my friend,
ever so much to
Jule and the
darling children.
Yours aff,
Jane]]
[[Written on right side--
Why didn't you tell us about the troubles? there?
How much are we to believe as what we
see in the papers?]]
Needs Review

he had charge of the Division field
hospital, where between one and two
hundred men were operated upon.
Coming home from Pittsburg Charlotte
travelled with a wounded soldier
from Frank's regiment, whose mouth
was filled with the praise of "Dr
LeMoyne." Would it not sound
funny to hear Frank called so?
We are subsiding here after
our dissipation here in the way of
riots. The election was not only
quiet but solemn. As usual the
borough gave a Democratic majority,
but the county gives a smell union
majority. Dick Fitzwilliams
is getting well, though he has suffered
much, and will be somewhat scarred.
Today he and Mr. Sweeney were
Needs Review

both released from jail, on bail.
We have no judge in this district,
Judge Lindsay having died recently,
so they brought over Judge Agnew from
Pittsburg, who gave the case a hearing
last night, and decided that they 
might be bailed. Mr. Reed, George
Morgan, Pa, and others uniting to 
give ten thousand dollars bail.
I mailed a paper to you today, containing
the evidence as far as it has been given.
Keeney, and Sarah Sweeney give the
most reliable statements, some of the 
witnesses cannot be believed, even on
oath. I think they must acquit
Dick, and his evidence will acquit Mr.
Sweeney. It was the sixth assault
Ben Brady had made that day, and
one of them was on a woman who
Needs Review

waved a black flag at the procession,
and Ben kicked her. Then he whipped
two boys who hurrahed for Lincoln.
A great many threats are uttered
against Dick and Mr. Sweeney, and I 
should not be surprised if some
farther violence were attempted, but
they don't seem afraid.
Nov. 16. Wednesday.
You see it takes a
long time to get a letter written. I
had to stop the other night
because of a severe pain in my eye,
which resulted in a swollen eye and
face that was perfectly hideous, though
not at all painful after the first
evening. Now it is all gone.
I fear I am going to have trouble
with my teeth this winter, they
have been aching several times. 
I have no doubt but I should be
better in Chicago, but I think I
had better stay at home this winter.
Ma is not perfectly well yet, and every
Needs Review

slight cold brings back her cough.
I should not feel easy to be
away from her this winter, but if
she keeps well through the winter
I will try and go to you in the
Spring, and Annie promises to
go with me and take Rose. I
want to go to Boston sometime
during the summer, return to
Chicago and spend the winter!
Is not that a grand air castle?
I doubt whether plans laid so
long beforehand ever come to much,
but I like to think I am going,
it will make the winter pass more
quickly to have something to look
forward to.
I'm very much obliged
to Mrs. Hubbard for her good opinion
Needs Review

of me, but as she never had much
opportunity of knowing me personally
she must get it from you, and
I'm inclined to think you are a
little partial in your opinion.
I am distressed to hear that apples
are so scarce, what will the
children do without them. There
are bushels lying around here that
we did not pick. If the boys had
their turnips here, they could trade
a peck of turnips for a bushel of
apples. If your apple-butter is
to be sent in cans, they will have
to be sent to Pittsburg, to Mrs. Murray
and how will she like that?
I don;t know whether I can get
any apple molasses. I make a little
bit, out of cider, and it took nearly
twelve quarts of cider to make three
pints of molasses, and then it was
rather sour. Julius has been making
sorghum syrup. He had about a third
of an acre planted, and from that 
had 70 gallons of syrup. It is better?
[[written up right side--
molasses and honey, I don't like it much.]]
Needs Review

[[Written on the left side --
Jane Recd Mar torn section
1865]]
398
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago
Ill.
Needs Review

Home. Feb. 25./65.
Dearest John,
You have a very bad memory
about letters. You thought Ma owed
you one, whereas you owed her two, so
how do you know but that you are in
my debt too. I do not positively assert
that you are, but somebody in Chicago
is, and it might be you. Anyhow
you ought not to say you will never
write to me again, because it hurts
my feelings. You ought to "heap coals
of fire" in my head, and overcome evil
with good. I really think though
I will have to reform. I get scolded
on all hands for not writing, and
the excuse of being busy does not 
always seem satisfactory.
[[Along left side of letter--
I forgot to acknowledge the draft I have not been in need for
Frank persists in
sending green-backs
to Sis + me every
time he is paid,
I have laid by
enough of what
he has sent
me to pay for 
my music
lessons.]]
Needs Review

I suppose Ma answered all your
questions, especially those relating to
the juveniles, about when you seemed
to feel so anxious. Did she give
you all the particulars, tell you how
many teeth the babies have, and
how many times they have each had
colds? Ma herself has not
been very well lately, she says it is 
rheumatism, but I think it is not.
She is never well when the weather
is bad that she cannot go out.
I think out cold weather is over, and
the reign of mud had begun.
Julius has been over in Pittsburgh
nearly all week, trying to find men
to fill up the quota for their township.
They raised the money, but could not
find men. I wish he could get
Needs Review

a substitute, and be rid of this
constant anxiety.
I believe Dick Fitzwilliams' trial has
bee postponed. It was before the grand
jury this week, and they had a very
stormy time. The district attorney, Jim
Ruth?, in making out the indictment
had altogether disregarded the coroners
verdict, and implicated Mr. Sweeney as
much as Dick, had neglected to summon
the most important witnesses, and did
everything he could to favor the Brady
side. Mr. Acheson + Will McRennan? were
very mad, and they almost came to 
blows over it. And now it will
wait until next court. The Bradys
say if the decision is in Dick's favor
they will carry it to the supreme court.
But I don't think Dick feels uneasy.
Needs Review

I'm afraid Annie will not keep to
her promise of going to Chicago in the 
Spring. They will begin to build as
soon as the weather will allow, and
she will think she is too busy to
leave home. Rose is a darling, so
funny and old-fashioned, and so good.
She does not talk much. You
would be surprised to see how Nannie's
baby has improved, it is right pretty
now. Nan thinks we are all partial
to Rose, which she does not like at
all. I see Miss? Paige's concert
in Pittsburgh was quite a success, I
hope she will please the Chicago people
as well. We are getting ready
for a concert here, for the Christian
commission, but do not expect it
will be anything extraordinary.
Much love to all, big and little, Yours aff,
Jane
Needs Review

[[Written on the left side--
Jane
Recd Mar 18/65]]
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago.
Ill.
Needs Review

[[Written on top of the page--
I will write to Jule soon.]]
Dearest John,
I received your letter
yesterday, and would have answered
it immediately, but was suffering
so with headache I could not
write. Of course I was
greatly relieved to hear from you
again, a great load is lifted
from my mind, though I hardly
thought you could be so hardhearted 
as to carry out your
threat.
Ma has been quite sick
for a week or two, with just
such a cold as she had last
summer, coughing terribly and
Needs Review

having severe pain in her
breast. She thinks she was
worse this time, but she
forgets. I am sure she has
not been so bad this time,
not near so much fever, now
so weak. She is better now
in some respects, her cough
is much better, and she
sleeps well again, but all
the cold seems to have settled
in her back and side, something
like rheumatism. She is very
lame, and cannot move without
great pain. She rides out
nearly every day, it is so warm
and pleasant, and it seems
to refresh her. It makes 
me feel very anxious when she
Needs Review

takes me of these heavy colds,
she don't seem to have strength
to react after such shocks.
I am very glad Jule
is getting along so nicely, I 
have wished a great many
times that I could be there, to
supply her appetite! About
the baby, I don't know what
to say, I am so surprised
and so pleased that you
should care to give her my
name, I did not know whether
to laugh, or cry over it, and
yet I think it is too bad
to give such an ugly name to
a child. I have always 
disliked it so much, and
am afraid she will, when
Needs Review

she gets old enough to care.
Suppose you reconsider, and
give her a better name, and
I will take the compliment
just the same. I cannor
promise to love her any more
than the others, for I don't
think that would be possible.
None of the other children
seem so near to me, unless
it is Rose, and hardly ever
Rose. Annie is not well
at all. She has chronic sore
throat, and seems generally
run down. Pa is giving her 
medecine, and she talks of
going home for awhile.
Julius is busy making his
preparations to build, they
will put the house in the
orchard. It is higher, and a
very pleasant situation, overlooking
all the farm this side
Needs Review

of the hill road. It will be
a plain, convenient, brick
house, nothing for show, but
all for comfort, a large
filtered cistern,ice-house
with cooling room, +c.
We hear from Frank often.
He seems to keep well, but says
the whole command is suffering
for want of vegetables, and proper
food, scurvy is appearing
among them. He has tried
in every way to have it remedied,
and seems quite indignant at
the authorities. I do think the
cavalry are neglected more than
the infantry.
Miss? Paige was delighted
Needs Review

with her visit to Chicago,
especially with Mr. + Mrs. LeMoyne.
You + Ma seem to agree about
her, Ma did not like her manners.
I don't think she has had
many advantages.
This evening is out concert,
we have the prospect of a very
large audience, which is the
main thing, what we want
is money.
I must stop, with very
much love to all. Tell
Granny to take good care of
that baby, until I come.
I don't know when that will
be. Ma thinks it would be
nice for her & Sis to go to the
fair in June. Good-bye,
With lots of love,
Jane
Needs Review

[[Written on left side--
Jane
Recd May 16/65]]
John V. LeMoyne.
Chicago
Ill.
Needs Review

Friday evening.
Dearest John
I received your
letter two or three days ago,
and waited to answer it, hoping 
to have more time, but I don't
see that I have gained much
for I am in a great hurry this
evening, but I think I ought
not to wait any longer.
I did not know whether to
laugh or cry over your letter.
I believe I did a little of
both. I don't know what
makes you all so good to me.
I'm sure I don't deserve it.
And, John darling, I did
not want you to send me
money. My wants here are
very few, and I think the
[[Written on the left side--
I am keeping 
house for Charlotte
while she is in
Pittsburg, and
have only a little
girl to help me.
Ma is better
than when I
wrote last.]]
Needs Review

summer will be almost gone
before I get away. I suppose
Ma wrote you of her plans.
Today we had a letter from
Frank, saying he hoped to be
home to go with them. I 
will wait here, very willingly
for the sake of having Ma go.
You know I would rather
be with you than anywhere, only
while Ma is sick. I can't bear
to leave her. I have been thinking
I might get a place in the
Seminary here, just for the sake
of being near her. I am almost
sure I could get a place then.
What do you think? As to being
your governess, that would be
only play. I should not feel
that I was doing anything.
I must stop, or this won't go
tonight. I will write soon,
Most aff, Jane
Needs Review

Home. April 24.
Dearest John.
You will think us very
negligent about sending this seed, I

Needs Review

Home. April 26. 1865.
Dear John,
You will be rather surprised
to get another letter from me so soon.
You see, I am acting out the "coals of
fire" doctrine. The truth is, I
want to talk to you a little while, about
domestic affairs, so put on your
thinking cap, and prepare to give me
your best advice. A decree has
gone forth, that henceforth Sis and I
are to be self-supporting machines,
no longer burdens on our poor father.
It cam about in this way. Last night
at tea those being only Ma and Pa
present, as he was pleasantly discoursing
on the weather +c Ma remarked that
Needs Review

it was time for us (Sis + me) to have
some Spring clothes, and that as he
had forbidden out making any bills,
he had better give us the money
to get them. He said "they have
money of their own, let them use that."
Ma, "You know what they have, and
that it would not begin to clothe them."
"Then," said Pa, "let them earn more.
They are doing nothing here, no use to
me, I don't want them, they 
may as well earn their own living."
+c +c. Ma reminded him that I
had received several offers of good
situations long ago which he would
not let me accept, but he declared
it was not so, that he had never
interfered with me in any way since
I had been of age, ten years ago!
Needs Review

Now, I don't see much way for
either of us to earn out living here,
the ground is all pre-occupied.
What suggestions have you to make?
only remember that what I want
is an independent way of supporting
myself. I won't come to Chicago to
be supported by you. I would
not like that, I want Pa to see
that I can earn my own living,
and glad to do it. But if you
can suggest any way for me to do
it, of course I would rather be with
you than any where else. I thought
of the school Carrie had, but am
a little afraid I could not manage
those rough children, and don't know
whether I am strong enough for that.
Do you think I could get some
music, scholars? I feel better fitted
Needs Review

for that, than anything else. Prof.
Wyman? says he will give me a
certificate of qualification!
Sis seems to incline to Pittsburgh, but
proposes that she should remain at
home until Frank comes home, then
go and take Ma with her. Of course
it is not of the question for Ma to
stay here without us, especially in
her present state of health. She
sees that, but can hardly bring herself
to say that she will go. We can't
and won't go without her Her
plan seems to be that she and Sis
should carry out their plan of going
to Chicago, I staying here until they
come back, which would be about
the last of June, then I am to
go, and they wait until Frank comes
for any further movements. Sis thinks
Needs Review

she has money enough, that Frank has
given her, to carry her through the
summer. I have not, much of
mine has gone for my music, and
I see now a special Providence in
my having taken lessons, it was
in preparation for this.
I don't much like the idea of being
a burden on my father for two
months longer, but will try to bear
it as far as my board goes. I 
have bought most of my own clothes
lately any way. Here, I can live
in calico. Out store bills for
a year, have been less than 150
dollars, for three of us, at the late
high prices, would you have thought
that too much for Pa to stand?
Needs Review

As for Ma, nearly all her clothes have
been given to her, for several years,
and indeed, if it had not been
for her children, she would have
suffered for proper food this winter.
Where a man does not support his 
wife, is not that sufficient cause for
leaving him? We do
not feel at all distressed at the 
prospect, but quite pleased. Sis says
"out free papers are made out."
Think it over, and tell me what you
advise. I received Jule's letter
today, but have not time to answer it,
just now. Maybe, if you can't find
anything else for me? to do, she would
take me as nurse or chambermaid!
Give much love to her, and all
the dear little ones. Yours aff, Jane.
Needs Review

June 11. Sunday Too
Dear Johnny, I have waitted untill
I could tell you I was coming, so we
start tomorrow, nothing preventing, in the
meantime, I cannot tell how long I shall
stay in Pittsburg, we may go on so or to
reach Chicago by Satuday or eve may
wait ten days. Sam Dook, who has
lately returned from California, is going
to Chicago in a few days, and for the
sake of company I may go a little sooner
& visit Romaine on my return, he is now
in Pittsburg, and I shall be better after to
decide when I get there, if I do not go
with him, you must pay him some attention
he seems a clever, steady fellow. I was
very greatly disappointed at Frank's
not coming home, it seems from his
last letter he wrote to us explaining his
situation &c, but we never received it
so when we received a letter telling us
he had already told us why we did not
come, and asking Me & Sis to visit him
Needs Review

we were quite suprised, he is at
Lynchburg and expects to be there all
summer. Sis is quite delighted at
the idea of her visit to Chicago,
but she was very anxious to go to
Lynchburg, but I could not think of going such
a distance alone. My health is
rather better, but I could bear any
exposure. Charlotte + Willie went
on to the review, and had a nice
time.
I am sorry to leave Jane alone but
don't know how to help it, She is
very unwell this summer, and
I shall be anxious about her.
Col. Wilson was married on the 8th
we were all there, and Sis was bridesmaid
, I shall receive? all news till
I see you. Much love to all,
Your loving Mother.
I shall write again when we decide
upon the day, or telegraph.
Needs Review

Needs Review

she will steal the hearts of the

but I could not have your

And I have just one request to

Nicholas. I am sure you do not

I think you had better be
writing to me, or I shall think

love to all,
Yours hastily,
Jane

1875
Monday morning.
Dearest John,
I don't believe any one
has written to you very lately, and
this dark wet miserable day is only
fit for sitting over the fire, and doing
indoor work. So, though I feel rather
lazy, I'm going to make an effort
to post you, as to matters + things
here. Sis has been scolding vigorously,
at all of you, because she can get
nothing but little scraps of notes out
of you, + nothing at all from Gran?
and Pete, and we cannot be content
with such scanty news.
We have been very forlorn here. It
seems as if we would never all be
well again. Nan has been very
ill again. She seemed to be
recovering so well, and had been

down stairs twice, when her disease

Washington Oct 30th
My dear brother,
I guess sit is your turn
to write to me but I can't wait any longer for
a letter. I have not commenced to study yet,
but will in a few days. Pa has gone to the farm
this morning + I take advantage of his absence by
writing to you, he + I get along very well so far
+ I think if I behave myself there will be no difficulty,
last night I stayed out till twelve o clock
+ he did not say a word. He says he is going to
Gallipolis as soon as the river rises. We'll have
a good time if he does. I think he is very
much pleased that I came back. He says nothing
as yet about emtying the room for Nan.
Mrs McKennan wants Charlotte to take one of her
rooms, the back room over the office, which Sam
Fairall occupied. She says she would be glad to have
Charlotte there. Nannie + little Charlie are

both very well. No two persons can agree? upon who he

looks like you. We all like tear in page hides word very much
but Ma is more pleased that any of use, it was Mr
H's choice. Willie gets along very well + is getting
fat, he says to tell Uncle Frank he wants to see him.
Last night the democrats had a torch-light procession but

Tell Romaine Ma will send her things on Friday by

you can, also my gloves, if you have no
comfort + want one keep mine as I don't need

cents. I think it would be best to sell

you get old if you live that long, you

no comfort to yourself or anybody else
you are forming habits for age, see to it

an imperious duty to work and provide
for the future, but not at the sacrifice
of duty. I take it to be every one's duty

enquiring minds, it is your duty to instruct

June 16"
Dearest Johnny, Alas it gives me very much pain not
to be able to comply with your just and rearmathe?
request. We are just as ready and desirous of going
as you can be to have and would start at a moments
warning, but what can we do, at one time we did hope
matters were mending a little, but at present our hopes
are dispelled. Poor Sis gets scolded and chastened
with locking up the parlor and forbidden to long? I & talk
on the steps &c &c. dear Frank is found fault with
continually and after he leaves the room. Pa says to us
that won't do if he does take care I will send him off
as quick as that (snapping his fingers) but we do not tell
Frank that, yet I very much fear he will not be able to remain
this his term, but not a hint of that to him, often he has
so much work to do and if any thing is neglected, he hears
of it, dear Johnny you have some idea of the wear & tear
of such a life you cannot douth? out sincere & earnest
desire to leave it even if we had not the deeply affectionate
wish to oblige you and to enjoy your presence and that
of your dear family. I don't know whence Pa drews
his conclusions that it is only one of John's freaks'
so I suppose he must think there is no real necessity.
As to Julius he gets along pretty well, he has a good
farmer with him, and then he is out of the way
Mr. Naset? has written to me that he is to sell a lot of
mine and would a deed? I gone Pa the letters about a
month ago but he has said nothing about it. The?
Needs Review

first payment was to be made in July. I expect he
will refuse.
I have received 165? dolalrs from Mr. Venton? for the scrip
so I shall have 300. I did think of sending it to you
by Mr Wills or would that be better than to leave it with
Mr Harding at six percent? I suppose there will be
hard times soon and I may get us more. MrVenton? 
thinks there will be a half yearly dividend in July and
I have empowered him to receive it. I expoect Pa will

he knew I was employing Mr. Vivton?, it was with his premission
yet he never has asked me about it. I do not willingly
do so but I really do not know what else to do, it is the
only way I can have a cent, and I must have a little.
Nicolas came with Romaine on Tuesday, yesterday they spent

they are at Charlotte's, to day we were to go to the farm

Julius is frinsing? in the wood today and stowing it in the

to Mary McClurg?. Big Will Quail thinks he made

Feb. 17" Thursday
Dearest Johny, I have just received your of 
yae? 14" I had been waiting for it some days so did not write you
am sorry you will be disappointed but I had nothing more to say untill
I heard form you. I once thought I should be glad to have you form?
an attachment, as it would settle you and incite you to virtuous
effort and laudable ambition so I think it would, had you made
a judicious choice, and whatever possessed you to go into such a
nest of hornets I cannot imagine. It seems to me I could
give up any body that had not despicable connections, for
I never could be happy with them, nor will you. I would
not let them so influence my future. I would have a little sense
and a great deal of independence, look at yourself, you would
do any thing to get such?, what for to please a set of poor
in every sense of the word, aristocratic, proud people, that would
just estimate you according to the length of your purse and your
willingness to share it with them, alas that out darling dearly 
beloved anxiously could for one should prove so secreant? to himself
should live, more and have his being or its the Murrays
filled the universe So I will not believe it, it will not always
be so. Love her, and if she be worthy as we not suppose
we will love her too, but you are under no obligations to the
rest, and need not care a cent what they want or think,
you are not forever to make every sacrifice to get rich, merely
because they want you to be so, that would be most miserable
subserviency,you are bound to make every honorable effort to 
obtain a comfortable living once to be a kind, agreeable husband
and I venture to say Julia will require nothing more.
As to rising at once to wealth and eminence, it is out of the question 
it will require much patience industry and economy and

Dearest Johnny March 13"
It is Sunday evening but I am going to write
you a few lines notwithstanding to inform you that we are all well,
which is something worth telling there times, we are not all very
well for I do not think Pa is quite so well, but he is undergoing
a good deal of fatigue just now, visiting? the Seminary 3 times
a day, morning and evening it takes him 2 hours to go the
rounds, and at noon about an hour or little more, then it
takes Julius an hour to put up the medicines, a common
semittent? fever has broken out there, quite unaccountably,
upwards of 20 me attacked. Many men able to go home
about a doyen? are now going thro' the course, only one
dangerously ill, and she took cold and has inflammation of the
lungs. the school has been dismissed and those teachers who
are not sick are very busy nursing those who are.
Shiea? of McKinnon's, Bell. Low? & Em. have it too, they think
they took it at the seminary, where they were playing, three cares?
at Wylonce's? and one or two others in the neighborhood.
The seminary has been too full this session. We have been
to help them several times but Pa thinks it is not safe to
go too often, the last two days Pa has been quite
unwell, he coughs? more than usual and is certainly losing
flesh. I wash him every sunday and find his arms getting 
very flabby. Mr. Newsom wrote again trying to show
that Mama could easily testify to what he wants so
Pa says he will see about it, he wants to take a trip
if he be able to int he spring, and will probably go to
Cincinnatti

Dearest John. I have but a minute to spare, but must tell
you how perfectly happy I was. I receive your sweet letter.
I think you are the kindest, best, most loving brother
imaginable, and love you accordingly. Strange that I
should for a moment think that you did not "love me
as I love you." and sure am I that "no knife can cut
our love in two." No, nor your love for Miss M. either!
You may love her just as much as ever you want to
and I shant say s word, but some of these times I'll
find a love myself, & then you'll be jealous, especially
if it should be Mr. Nickolas R. Wade! Dont you think
you could make up your mind to like him, & not think 
him "an old granny"? I begin to think I was rather
hasty in my rejection of his addresses, & dont know but
I might let him renew them, if you would only give him
your full approval. I'm getting mighty tired of this
sort of a way of living, & would like almost anything
for a change. Miss Thomas
has gone, and Jane's face was a mile long for two days,
but Jule & I succeeded in making her smile by the
end of the second day, and by the third morning she
laughed out loud - (Romaine is exercising her exaggeration powers
wonderfully. I did not know they were capable of such expansion)
I suppose Ma informed you of the doleful state of affairs
at the Sem. And as Julia was not at all well & lived out we
make her come & stay two or three days here to get nomited? +
Miss Thomas was here Monday, Tuesday & Wednesday. Then Jule
came on Thursday, & went home on Saturday eve. I think you
Needs Review

would like each other now. Jule says "tell John I wish
he had a pain of seven? league looks? and would stop any him some day for I have a great desire
to shake hands with him." She was here just after I got 
your letter & so I gave her your message. We had a laugh
over old times. And Jule says she is becoming lamentably?
amiable, & has more tender, than tinder in her composition,
that her friends are getting afraid that they'll soon get her
off their hands for she has not preserved? enough of her
original spunk wood? & fire to light a match. There! Cant she
make awful puns? Almost as bad as yours, indeed I 
think sometimes theyre emse?, You and Ma & Jule would
have a good time together I think. But goodbye, my
dear darling brother. Frank is waiting to take
this to the office. I'll write again the last of 
the week. R-.
Needs Review

John V. LeMoyne. Esq.
Chicago.
Illinois.
Needs Review

My Dear daughter April 10"
Your affectionate and very gratifying letter
of the ninth only reached me yesterday, we were beginning to
think it very strange that we did not hear from you and
had it not been for the telegraph, I should have probably 
been in a state of uneasiness, by no means enciable, but my
confidence in John's regard and consideration of me, assured
me that he would have forwarded a message had any thing
disastrous occurred. I am delighted indeed that you find yourself
happy and experienced no disappointment in your expectations which
must certainly be a cruel trial to a young confiding? heart.
I think tho that John is not disposed to impose upon or deceive
I have always thought he presented his worst front to the
world, but to the reason of his choice, whom of aruse? he was
anxious to please he might have been led unconsciously to
appear better thou he was, if he has, I hope he will try to
be in reality what he has ever wished you to think him. We
are such creatures of habit that the effort itself to be amiable
really enables us to form the character. So I advise you to keep
him to it, which I dare say you will, by example. So that I know
of no better advice to give you that to love and hear with each
other, always remembering that it is the lot of poor? humanity
to have failings, but the duty of christianity to bear each
other's burdens. May you be enabled to look to the right source
for help and strength and blessed in the discharge of every duty.
I regretted very much that you could not remains longer with 
us. I loved you because of your love for John, as I felt that it
Needs Review

must be strong to enable? you to take the step you did, for you
were both opposed, and discouraged on all sides, for John 
was sadly berated for forcing himself iinto an unwilling
family, and gravely warned against the consequences &c,
but all would not do it seem, and here we find ourselves 
rejoicing in the face of all our opposition you and me mean to love 
to know how favorably you have impressed? us, the boys were asked if they 
liked their new sister, a very emphatic yes indeed, was sure
to be answered, if you have been spoiled in the way of love 
and affection you have come to the right place, for ours is a family 
of pets. I hope John will suceed but I fear it will not be 
safe to induce him to relax his efforts or mingle much in society 
instead of helping his business, it will interfere and hinder 
as a general rule if is not the most social and apseable? part 
of the community that are the most useful to a man of business,
he must labor with untiring industry, and close attention,
and if you had a house you would have to do so too, so if 
I were you I would not begin by visiting much, you can 
increase your circle better than diminish it when it 
with your circumstances to do so.
I know it will please John to know that Uncle Vinton? thinks
he has made a wise selection in a situation, but insists 
perhaps more than I do, on a patient, persevering devotion
to business and study, he is pleased with what he has heard of 
John and may possibly throw business in his way, he has been 
employed in a suit of a mining company that is to come on this 
summer at Detroit. John may know something of it and as he 
is quite a traveller he might possibly visit Chicago.
Needs Review

I made a rather pleasant visit of a week to Gallipolis. What do you 
think of my taking your daguerotype with me! I knew my friends 
would want to see what John's wife looked like, perhaps I had 
better not tell John the admiration it elicited. I more say he 
is vain enough, already, of his wife, so you need not tell him 
Uncle Vinton thought her 'handsome' too. I read your letter 
to Mama, she was quite delighted, interrupting me frequently 
with ejaculations and concluded it was a very satisfactory and
desired very much love to you. Write to me whenever you
feel like. I shall always be glad to hear from you, write
with freedom and confidence and be assured of sympathy
and affection. Be not easily discouraged, all have difficulties;
to overcome, but none treat the rough path of life so easily
as those who are cheered by the warm smiles of affection.
The boys and Sis send much love, Frank says he loves
John better now. Believe me my dear daughter
your affectionate Mother, M. LeMoyne.
Dear Johnny. I should not know to begin to love you any less
just now, but I cannot promise for the future, but I do not
expect any change. I did not love the way in which you treated
your Sisters upon a recent occasion but we have concluded
to forget the past by loving in future, and only ask that you
appreciate what we so cheerfully bestow. I must repeat to 
you our regret at the shortness of your visit, which you know
is pretty good evidence of the pleasure it gave us.
The people in Gallipolis were as much surprised as in Washington
I was gone to G. just a week, did not go to Buffalo, as Dr. Noset? and
family were in G. on a visit. Uncle Vinton was there too, so we had a
Needs Review

plesant time. I came as far as Morietta? with Mr. Winton, he was going
there on business, he only engages in important suits now, one takes
him to Detroit this summer. I wished him to go and see you 
at first he thought he might be in Chicago, but it is doubtful,
he thinks you will certainly succeed if you apply yourself
closely and singly to your profession, and thinks Chicago
would suit Mr. Wills. Says Wills has talent and if he would
apply himself to his profession would damde?. I hope he
will suit himself in a situation short of Col. or Texas 
my poor dear Charlotte how could I let her go so far from
me, We find Father's business rather entangled, old unsettled
accounts rising up occasionally, that may make trouble, but
Naret? thinks he can settle them, business is dule? and property
not in demand just now, but they still talk of railroads +.
The Miami railroad stock is the best part of the estate yielding
ten percent. I received from Mr. Vinton 50 dollars as my share
of the half year's dividend, and a quarter's sent for the house
if has given a little spending money to the girls. Charlotte thinks
I had better spend the next in a visit to Chicago & the lakes,
time enough yet. I saw Mr Newsom but Mama cannot testify
to what he requires. Uncle Vinton has not a particle of confidence
in his honesty, so we had better have nothing to do with him.
I stand with Mrs. LeClercy, they were very kind and seem very
glad to see me had been looking for me a week. I saw Dr. Happ?
& wife in Wheeling they board at the Munro house where I stopped
she is quite pretty and pleasant and they seem very happy ofcourse
Bill Kister? found fever + ague where he went so turned and came home
I believe he arrived saturday night. I have heard no particulars says he
left your package where you would get it. Very much love to you
be a very very good boy, be saving? and industrious &c&c you know whatelse
I am quizzing? you now no goodbye, dear boy, affectionately yours M. L.M.
[[Written up right side--
Bill staid allnight in Chicago but could not find you
left the package with a man who said he knew you,
and would give it to you.

Dearest Johnny July 4"
Indeed I have not forgotten at all, you are continually
int he recesses of my heart, but I knew you were happy, and busy
about your own affairs and would not think of feeling neglected
if I did not write to you. I felt afeared also that we might be
silent a while and suffer no dimuntion? of affection. I have
had so many things to try me? dear Johnny, but I greater one
is not upon me, you need no introduction to know I speak
of Romaine's madness, it deserves no other name to think of
her entangling herself with such an hideous, conceited, disagreeable
little piece of deformity as Nick. I wish his namesake had
him, no not exactly, but I wish he was in Guinea or Australia
Pa and I feel that we have been greatly imposed on and
advantages taken of us by that family. Well the little fool
wrote to all of us, his fulsome? letters, I would not take mine
at first and was very angry with Romaine. Pa answered his
and invited hiim over, that he might see him! and so when
he came he was so shocked with his mean and daorpit? appearance
he knew not what to do, he wished a talk with me. I told
him plainly. I was too much shocked and surprised to give
an answer and positinecy? declined committing myself in any
wat for the future &c&c, but had no objections to his family or
his character and standing, Talk? him too I was very much
offended that the thing had been done in his Father's house
and I thought they had both acted very sarbly? and improperly
Pa told him much the same and that his appearance
indicated a very feeble conste whou? and consequently bad
health, which osiction? he conidesed? sufficient and
permanent

+ I latebag? these only? expression I was too much excited I care try? to think

Nick said he had excellent health and a strong constitution

the Wades have managed? her this time. Mr. Wills says he

broken off altogether and your must help me.
They have promised to wait as long as I wish, it will be

Poor Pa is visibly declinging, state? suffers very
much, is feeble and coughs a good deal and has ugly
Needs Review

mattery? expectations. It makes my heart ache to look at him

My own health has been very bad this summer and I am thin

I would not promise to hold out against Romaine's sacrifice
I cannot resist anything now my frail old body just sinks and

When I was in Gallipolis Mr Lupper? told me she knew Jupage folded
