We have a great deal of honey and I should like to send you a couple
of boxes, we have been almost living on raspberries and intend to
make plenty of jam, perhaps an extra jar. Charlotte is picking currants
today for jelly I believe she intends to make an extra glass. I think you will
find housekeeping more than boarding unless you are extremely economical
which I doubt a little, but you must learn like other people,
it is not very economical to have visitors, I can tell you, but it is a 
very good plan to have a very small house. I would not advise
Julia to begin with Miss Leslie. There is nothing plain or practicalle
about her, Miss Beechen is better. I am sure I should like to have
Romaine go and teach you to make bread, she is pretty good at
but I suppose now I need not hint going abroad. Pa says I was always
for letting them go on a this is? what comes of it. I think it is because
they do not go enough, Mr. Wade wanted Lizzie to make a visit of several
weeks, but our family is alone? and I had no girl, tho' I have now.
some declined, on the name? of Pa's dislike to noise and Charlotte's situation
Mr. Wills is still with us. Someone told me the other day you smoked
I hope it is not two, you know what I miserable, disgusting habit
it is, besides I am sure it would be extremely injurious to you
do dear Johnny do quit it immediately, your wife will love
you a great better for it, you much consider that every little slavish?
disagreeable or even natural defect or habit tends greatly to weaken
the affections, one should be a great deal more cautious after marriage
than before, a neglect of any kind that would scarcely be noticed before
will produce a very servible diminution? of admiration and esteem
often marriage, a woman can excuse a fault in a lover but she wants
her husband to be perfect, so that others as well as herself may look up to him as
a model. So be ye perfect, abounding in every good work. Give much love
to Julia, I appreciate her kindness and affection to me fully. I will write to her
but you know how lazy? I am. God Help you both with what is best for you
Very affectionately yours M LeM.

Very dear Johnny August 30"
Altho I wrote to you this morning I must write
again to-night, for how can I sleep when I think of my poor boy's
distress, how very much do I feel for you and O how do I wish
I could be with you. I must certainly see you soon, how uneasy
and miserable your letter has made me, how bitterly have I wept 
and how earnestly have I prayed this day, and could I know my 
dear boy would meet me at the throne of grace what a comfort 
would it be to me, there alone can I find peace. I know 
that my Father afflicted not willingly, and I hope in his mercy.
Love him dear John and he will reward you with an eternity 
of such bliss as you have not even imagined, may he 
indeed bless you, watch over you, and save you.
I cannot rest untill I hear good news from you 
I have spent much of this day in my room a few more 
such would lay me up, then will you not come 
to me. O I cannot think you would do so cruel 
a thing as to go away again. I cannot endure that 
thought for a moment, do dearest John say that you 
will not go, and that you will try to compose yourself 
and do well. I have read your letter over and over untill 
I am afraid to read it again, for I cannot read it without 
weeping. I was greatly tempted to-day to send a dispatch 
enquiring for you. I must do so if I do not hear soon 
I hope I shall get another letter in a day or two.
Needs Review

How much you would expose yourself by going away or giving up 
to such a grief. Master it succeed in business and show her what 
she has thrown away. What objection can you have to remain 
where you are you have said your prospects were good, do 
not destroy them. You think now you care for nothing, but 
surely such a state of mind cannot last, you certainly have 
more manliness and fortitude than that, besides what object 
would you attain thereby, not even the respect of the woman 
who has injured you, you say would rather have died.
O my son 'tis not so easy a thing to meet the King
of terrors, besides after death comes the judgement 
and an eternity of misery is too dear a price for 
a little unhappiness, a little fleshly indulgence.
Altho you may have anticipated much happiness in the 
attainment of your wishes, there were older and wiser heads 
who had their misgivings, married life is not always a 
paradise, again I must entreat you dear boy, to remember 
that your sorrows are mine. O write me a word 
of comfort, say that you will not go away, but rather 
come home, forget not the strength of my love and the 
weakness of my frame to endure so great an affliction, 
Frank Barton? has been here several days he is now in 
a bad attack of mania at Mr. Wilson's.
much love from your devoted Mother, M LeMoyne
Be sure to let me know if you are sick.
So I can come and nurse you.
Needs Review

every time any one came in today I have expected a 
dispatch saying you were sick. God bless and protect 
my dear boy. I cannot close this morning without again 
entreating you not to do anything rashly, my anxiety and grief for 
you are very great. Am I not worth living for, if not, let me die, 
you will hasten to relieve my overburdened heart will you not?
you wile? away the tears of your Mother and comfort her broken heart? 
you will nobly forget your own sorrow to pour consolation into the 
bosom of age, age that has so few wordly? comforts and so 
many trials is it not deserving of a little of your love and solace.
I need not ask it. I know your kind and generous heart will 
respond to my demands. I know my darling boy will crush his 
Mother's bleeding heart by a selfish gratification of passion 
Reason will resume her throne point out the path of duty.
No one ever has or ever will love you like your own
affectionate Mother.
Needs Review

Dearest Johnny Sept 7"
I fear I trouble you but I want to write 
to you to night so you must bear with me. I was truly 
glad to receive your letter but offended that you should 
send mine back, dear John burn as many as you please but
never send another back. I do not suppose you intended 
to hurt my feelings so let us say no more about it. I am very 
sorry indeed if I said anything to hurt yours. I know I am hasty 
and excitable where my children are concerned but you have no idea 
of the depth of foolishness there? is in a mothers love, unfathomable 
and inextinguishable. I was sadly distressed at your sorrow and truly 
sympathised with you, and dear John how flattered I felt by 
your confiding love, how it strengthened my confidence in you. 
So don't regret is but let me feel and know that whatever 
happens to you whether of good or evil I shall know it, then 
would a load of anxiety be removed from my heart. I am not 
particularly anxious that you should remain in Chicago nor 
that you should pursue the law, if it is irksome to you, nor can 
I expect you to be with me (that would be too good), but as you are 
established and likely to do well I think you ought to persevere in it.
It would add very much indeed to my happiness to see you 
often, you know all my wordly happiness is centered in my children,
but I cannot ask them to make any great sacrifices for me,
this winter will probably try your Father's health very severely,
should he be taken to whom could we look but to you
Needs Review

look into the future and reflect upon the consequences before you 
abandon a profession that has already cost you so much, for an 
uncertainty, I know not to what you allude, but you certainly 
cannot think of a wandering business when you speak of going to 
other places, you say you still have a little hope destroy it not 
by lowering your position too much, you must explain yourself 
more fully before I can advise or encourage you. I must confess 
any confidence in you has been increased by the way, you have acted 
in this matter, you will laugh at the idea, but do you know I 
feared you would storm? off in a fit of gloom and I should never 
see or hear from you again, was it any wonder I was in such 
distress, but I kept close and was only not well, but dearest 
Johnny if you will only continue your confidence to me 
I will promise to do better and not go crazy again.
You don't know how many trials I have and how it lightens them 
and quietens my life to enjoy the love and confidence of my children.
Tell me all your plans and wishes, your ups and downs all that 
concerns you interests me, moreover I will not misjudge whom 
you approve. I do not consider you a child, but you know you 
have not much experience in the world yet, but you are a dear good 
boy and I think you will never regret paying some deference 
to your mother's wishes. I cannot tell what you would do, what 
would amuse? you &c&c. you say it is not wrong. I hope not 
but I can say nothing until I know, but I let me advise you 
to do nothing your father would disapprove.

Mr. John LeMoyne
1852
Chicago
Illinois-
Needs Review

Sept. 20"
Dearest Johnny, Only think of it. I have not heard from you for 
two weeks! I can scarcely believe it, and yet it seems very long, and I am getting 
very uneasy. I have waited day after day to write thinking I would certainly hear 
from you but no letter has come yet, your last dates the 4.", is not that long, 
particularly under present circumstances. I am beginning to conclude you 
are sick, but hardly know how I can wait for an answer to this, hope you 
would certainly send a dispatch. I feel esier? now that Mr. Wills is 
with you, do dear Johnny tell me all about yourself frankly. 
Romaine received a letter from Miss Muney? today, from Phila. on her way 
home and cocided? R. to write her immediately to Pittsbr, no explanation of 
how conduct, but seems to take it for granted R. knows the state of affairs 
and wishes not to be condemned unheard &c. and ends as much in 
such cares? with, say nothing about it. I do not see the use of 
keeping friends so much in the dark when, generally speaking, 
Tout le monde knows all about them, it is neither fair not 
kind, if near and dear friends were more confided in it would 
often prevent michief. She says she has been very wretched 
during her trip. As soon as you read this you had better burn it 
do you think of coming home this fall and how soon?
As William Wills is gone I suppose you have given up Texas,
We were supposing today, the profibility of your again boarding 
with Charlotte, not in Pitts. but Chicago. I should go to see you 
I think. Indeed I wanted to go this fall, but Pa seems altogether 
unwilling to have me go even to Gallipolis, wonders why in the 
world I should go &c. He is so easily worried now, I do not want
Needs Review

to contradict him, he continues about the same, feeble, stiff, pained and 
coughing, and sore throat. Mama thinks he has consumption and will be bad 
this winter, she is beginning to think he is rather strict and queer.
and I tell you I had spoked to Mary Ann to take Maddie, well she went on saturday,
it was their Father's wish that they should never be parted, and I think they ought 
to be together, besides Maddie was not happy with me, indeed she was alone 
I was really very much distressed about her, for I could not make her happy,
now we are relieved and they are happy, all done very pleasantly and kindly,
we have been wishing for you and Charlotte tho last week to help us eat peaches
We have a great many, and we are afraid every night they will be taken,
some are taken every little while, perhaps every night a few, still 
we have plenty for eating and preserving, and pies everyday, wine apples 
are about done, fruit is rather scarce generally. 
I believe Mr Riall? goes on wednesday, so will probably be in Chicago 
on friday or saturday and take you two shirts, tell us how they ffit.
Sarah cut them and Nannie made them, we will direct him to your 
office or Sherman house. I have a great mind to put in a wine 
apple and tell him, if he should be delayed to look at it.
I have not heard from Mr. Vinton, but Charlotte tells me Sarah is gone to some 
springs in Virginia.
Do try to write to some of us one? a week, if you are not too busy. 
Very much, O how much love to you dearest Johnny,
your affectionate mother M. LM.
Needs Review

Needs Review

Sept 30"
Dearest Johnny, the short, hurried and unconfiding manner of your 
leter today poirs? me sadly, fills my mind with uncertainty and fear 
I have long struggled against the painful apprehension that you were 
loving? your affection for home and friends, the afflictions certainly 
seems now before me and the only alternative left me is to lose 
you forever or see you wretched because you have to be near me, 
either way I must be miserable, from some expression in your letter 
I infer that my letters have greatly annoyed you, in much love and 
great anguish have they been written. I had been happy in your 
confidence and love, but mind you do not see fit to inform me 
of course I have nothing to say, feel is another thing, when you do 
come it will only be a day or two ((to some appearances)!! 
God forgive my poor boy for his cruelty= As to your going 
to Texas, you greatly misunderstood my silence. I knew William 
was gone and concluded you would soon think better of such 
a mad caper. I did not think you so wholly estranged as to 
desert me during your Father's very precarious state of health. 
I begin to feel doubtful whether he survives the winter 
Perhaps report may inform us of your affairs, as we sometimes 
hear more that way than any other. I am glad you have important 
business. I suppose your premonitory? symptoms increasing.
Mr. Rial? will not go now untill after the election.
'Tis painful and mortifying to know nothing about your movements 
but if you do conclude to come, need I send your shirts by 
Rial, the town has been quite full and busy with its annual 
exercises, all fine of course, today concludes.

there has been much sickness in the country and some in 
town, we are all as usual -I was not- Alf. Words died

well, well, again I say much love

Oct 14"
Dearest Johnny, Thou art 'my own? kind dearie'
and fully do I appriciate thee, yes fondly do I love and 
continually do I remember my beloved boy, entreating 
for him happiness and protection from all evil, and He 
who has said ask and ye shall recieve, is not only able, but 
willing to grant us out reasonable requests, but he is infinite 
wisdom, and ways and means are in his own hands.
Let us then love him with all our souls and he will return 
us a thousand fold in this life and in that which is to 
come, unspeakable bliss. Surely this were worth trying 
to obtain, how the things of time dwindle into nothing 
repenten? out thoughts are fixed on eternity, as long 
as we are in the world we are studying our professions? 
for eternity, how vastly important then that they should 
be of the right kind, that is the cause of all my anxiety 
for my children, not that they should be great or sick, but 
that we might all spend an eternity of happiness together 
forever woshipping infinite Wisdom and love and 
admiring infinite beauty in God's whole universe 
ever and anon looking back upon the thorny and 
devious path we had on earth, now stripped of all its 
misery. O dear Johnny, won't that be joyful indeed 
I have never deceived you, believe me 'tis worth living? 
for.
Needs Review

It distresses me so much to think that you are not happy and 
that you should not shine against such feelings, dear boy 
it must not be so, every effort at resistance will give you 
strength for another, and why make yourself and me 
wretched, it is not better to resist evil and be happy.
promise me to try, I know you will succeed, for you have 
a strong will and a good heart, and I know it, if I did 
reproach you, was not I ugly? but you are kind 
and considerate to answer me so affectionately, indeed 
I guessed you would, so you see I do know you, and 
I do know you can take care of yourself, but how can 
I part with you under such painful circumstances,
you can scarcely imagine all I suffered when you 
went away. I really feel as tho' I could barely endure 
a repetition of the heartrending operation, dear Johnny 
you have often, often lent an ear to your Mother's pleadings 
I cannot believe you will now turn away. I do 
not ask you to remain in Chicago or to continue your 
profession. I only ask and entreat you not to go 
away from me, and to love me, I am sorry you 
cannot come yet. I have been keeping some 
plums on the trees and some apples for you 
every time I eat, grapes, apples or anything else 
I think of you and wish I could send you some. 
Pa is not better, he still coughs and gradually grows
Needs Review

thinner tho slowly, has a little fever almost every evening 
and sometimes night sweats, says he cannot take medicine 
it makes him so sick at stomach and would prevent 
his eating and then he would go right down, 
then if you were away, what should I do? 
Charlotte says Lou is so ill, at Tanerville?, his Father 
has to go on with him to W. I believe he has dyspepsia? 
John Wills is going to join William in January.
Uncle Vinton wants me to -go to- be in Gallipolis by the 25th 
this month court week at the division. I suppose 
I will go, Pa intends giving up the management of 
Val's estate, and wishes to give up Mama's, then there 
will be mine, how would you like to take them all.
'Would keep you in employment, I have heard that 
Dr. Lane intends going soon. Yesterday, the boys, Sissy and I went to Mr. Von Kuik's? 
in the buggy, walking up the hills, 'twas very pleasant and the boys got plenty 
of nuts, we talked of you (as usual) and I thought a good hurt? or two over 
out beautiful hills would do you so much good, today was the cattle show 
tomorrow the fair, the Society has leased the Major's corner field, fenced 
it and put up a shanty for the the manufacturing and floral 
exhibition, admittance, ten cents. Mr. Hopkin is elected canal 
commissioner. A. Gow brought home his bride and had a reception 
on monday. Bob Haglit? and J. Cummins are to be on saturday with 
theirs, and have one at Floglet's?, returning from Phila. I have put 
up lots of tomatoes expecting you to help us eat them. Stoy 
still talks of building at the corner.
Needs Review

Oceans of love to out own dear Johnyy, absent but 
ever present in out affections and prayers.
Be happy and strong anf yield not to the temptation 
that assails you but vise? with calm dignity 
over the heartless cruelties of the world and 
place your affections on a surer foundation, but 
crush them not, for in time or in eternity they 
must constitull? your happiness. Day unto day 
and night unto night bear testimony to my 
loving aspirations for my dear lonely boy.
Your own affectionate Mother,
M. LM.
Needs Review

Nov 21"
Dearest Johnny
My last letter to you was so unfinished. I have 
felt ever since as tho' I had not written. I have put off writing 
to you so long waiting for yours that I thought I could not wait 
any longer and just then I was hurried. I began to tell you why 
you were so good a boy and forgot to tell you, but the reason I 
felt it so much just then. Sam Doak was gone to California 
and his poor Mother was in great affliction. I felt very much 
for the poor boy for he seemed to be forced away, people were 
telling him he should not be loofing? here on his Mother, as if it 
were any of their business, that he ought to go to California &c &c
and as John Henderson was going he persuaded Sam to go too
his Mother was very unwilling at first but finally yielded
he has letters to N. York from Colin Reed and if he can find 
employment he will go no further. Alas, what suffering 
and distress have to be endured for this truly accursed? gold 
and how little of real happiness does it confer when once 
obtained, indeed it is oftener a source of misery and 
death temporal and eternal.
I hope you are well again. I am constantly anxious lest you 
should get sick and I could not get to you, O better live 
together on a little than be so separated. It makes me so 
sad to think of having you and Charlotte away. I cannot think 
it is right and I know it is dreadful.
Needs Review

I hope you will both be happy, and I will try to be content.
I have not heard from Charlotte for some time nor Sarah 
Romaine received your letter yesterday, how bad it is 
to have our letters delayed so. I thought the railroad was 
completed now and there would be no more detention.
I am glad you are so comfortable and happy, if you are satisfied 
so am I, and hope I can forgive the past, you ought to be the best 
judge of what will make you happy, but 'tis the best way 
not to let such things affect us too much, one way or 
the other. I think you would not again. 
Poor Mrs. Barch? has returned to her brutal husband, her Mother 
is dead and she says she does not care now what becomes of her 
She will follow him wherever he goes, he has got into bad 
company, drinks, and abuses his wife & children very much 
She is said to look like a shadow. I do pity her indeed, but do 
not know what can be done.
Pa continued about the same rather better than when you were 
here but still coughs. 
The synod have taken the College who then hands and appointed 
trustees and faculty and a Mr. Scott of Wheeling, president 
the faculty remaining except Mr Less who has resigned.
Some of the Trustees, being opposed to the arrangement have 
resigned. What kind of a place would Chicago be for Roy 
Gragnom?, he graduates in the spring, and they think of his 
going there. You will have quite a colony of Washington
Needs Review

people if all go who are talking about it. 
I have been sitting up with Romaine who has had a rather 
sick night, so I thought I might as well write to you, but 
it is after 5, and I must either wake Jane and go to bed or go 
and get breakfast. I think Romaine must have taken some 
cold and will be well after she sleeps. She says she is going 
to write to you, so she may finish this sheet, if not 
she will write soon all well and send a great deal of 
love to you. I don't believe you know how much we love you dear 
Johnny, and how often we think and speak of you.
I suppose by this time you are quite busy, happiness 
peace & love to my beloved boy M. LeMoyne
It is time to mail this and Romaine is trying to sleep so 
of course she cannot write today but I will send, if only this 
that you may know we do not forget you
Needs Review

Nov 13"
Dearest Johnny, I have waited day after day for 
your letter and it only came today post marked 9".
I did not feel uneasy for several reasons, in the first place you 
very considerately dropped me a line, and then I thea? I have had a 
load removed from my heart, in seeing you and knowing somewhat 
of your status quo. I knew where you were going and what you 
were going to do, you had established pleasant relations with 
your Father and gaining more of his confidence, your prospects 
in every respect as good as could be expected, then the fiery 
ordeal thro' which you well? posing was doing you good. So 
tho I could almost forgive the cruel and heartless instrument 
so that altho' your presence was precious and dear to me I could 
let you depart in hope, I was sorry to hear of your detention or, 
rather of your delay in P. I did not insist on your staying here another 
day than you might have no excuse for travelling on the sabbath, and 
ahead heard that you had so anaryed? for the sake of remaining 
one day in P. I felt hurt, I hope you will always make your 
anouzement?, both or business & pleasure so as to observe the sabbath 
indeed I think you might find or take time to write letters 
some other day, you will never lose by obeying the commands of 
God. I have felt lately more than ever what a dear good boy you were 
to me, I will tell you why directly, but are you as good, kind and 
confiding to your kind and loving Charlotte, she says she saw so very 
little of you, you know she loves you and would have been so delighted 
to see more of you.
Needs Review

You have probably heard all about poor Lou's death. It is my opinion 
he has been killed by homeopathic medicine, did you ever hear 
of such a rapid case of dyspepsia. I am anxious to hear how 
Sarah is, poor things how little good their riches did them.
Well the estate is divided and each share estimated at 4,300 
the corner store and 3 court house lots with a 50 acre lot on mill 
creek, to Sarah the house, 25 feet next to hart and 2 court house 
to me, nexto me on the square to May. she next to Maddy 
and next to Mrs. Lupper?. Mary with a lot in Wilkesville, 
a lot adjoining mine on second street to May & Maddy, 
then there must be about 5,000 dollars of Bank stock.
I am just as well pleased that I did not go down, Dr. Hard? 
tell, me some Doctor wants the house. I have told him to 
sent it for what it will bring. We have thought Pa a 
little better tho he says he is still losing flesh steadily at the 
rate of a pound a week. Dr. Read has lost his last daughter 
of dysentery too. he now has 7? sons. Did Dr. Loue? give you 
your brush. I sent it by him, or perhaps he did not take it 
I will enquire. Lou Layon was married last week. Maggy 
this morning at 5 and left for the east. Julia Robertson 
is come, she is just the same.
Our girl left us on saturday, so you may think of us as in 
a state of healthful activity. 
I must not express myself on the subject of what you 
call bamboozlement the heart said, so went mended 
You know no part of it ever had my appritation? except the unclear
Needs Review

but I have confidence in your judgment and as to the rest,
nous venons. I suppose you don't care much about 
the news, if you do I must disappoint you this time.
Did you write to Riall, he has been asking if you had 
sent him any message.
Bushels of love to our dear Johnny. I am so glad 
you are nice and comfortable. I did not half enjoy 
my own comforts when I thought of your privations? and 
troubles. very much love from your own affectionate 
Mother M LeMoyne.

Decr. 6"
Dearest Johnny
I fear you think us very neglectful, altho 
you owe me a letter. I intended writing last week but 
thought Jane was doing so, the fact is we have been very 
busy. Romaine was sick two weeks, from what I supposed 
was cold, not as usach? on her lungs but affecting the stomach 
& bowels to such a degree as to produce extreme suffering 
and very great prostration? and tedious recovery.
She does not yet feel well but is able to go out some. 
As we have no girl, the work and the sick nursing? 
kept us bodily busy and mentally lazy, add to this 
the receiving of calls and making a dozen winter shirts 
&c&c and you will believe we have been pretty 
conscienably? engaged. I expect an irish girl this week 
a good honest willing creature who knows nothing 
or next thins to it. Nannie and Jane have had a little 
those of the prevailing influenced but we are all well just 
now. I thought Pa better for a while, but for the last few 
days he has coughed so much and his throat looks so 
badly I can hardly think he is improving much, tho 
he is stronger and eats as usual and sleeps a little better 
but looks badly.
I have not heard from Charlotte for some time but heard 
last week that she did not look well, poor child
Needs Review

I fear she will fret about her husband. I suppose you 
know he has lost his suit, as might have been expected,
I do not think he ever meant to be dishonest or dishonorable 
but his code of morals is not built on the only true foundation,
religion, consequently liable to error, beware 
dearly beloved that you fall not into the same more.
It is my daily prayer that you be kept from temptation 
and sin and guided into paths of integrity and holiness.
Frank Barton came here from Wheeling whither he had 
gone on business about some serape? he got into last summer 
on a boat I believe. I do not know whether he got 
decenk? before he arrived but he had an attack of mania 
at Valentine's. Mr. Wilson came in immediately and 
took him out home. Where I understand he intends 
remaining for some time, he says he cannot keep from 
drinking in Pitt.b., but never drinks at Mr. Wilson's
and he is now anxious to reform, poor fellow I fear 
he will find it very difficult.
Tom Logan was married sometime since and Maggy 
soon after after the bridal trips they had a double 
reception last week. Nannie & Jane went Romaine 
was hardly well enough.
We have had out front door improved after a pattern from Mr.
Chirlet? two fluted pillars supporting a flat roof with 
high frontis piece, enlarged entrance with a recess and 
side lights to the door, office door merely a new frame
Needs Review

a little heavier than the old one with a frontispiece that 
looks like a sijer? right against the wall, people say 
it is a great improvement, very pretty &c. I suppose 
we will find it pleasant and comfortable. I do not 
care much about it. 
The house in Gallipolis is rented] to a Dr. Smithey 
I suppose for 100 dollars, tho young Catiny? who 
is due at College says such houses do not bring 
more than fifty. Our college has posed? the rubicon 
and is now in the hands of the synod, the home elected 
a Mr. Scott of Wheeling for President to come in the 
Spring. I forget whether I told you before. We have now 
about 80 students. Mr. Less who has resigned goes to 
Wheeling to practice law, his family will remain here 
untill fall.
Old Mr. Gordon has an attack of paralysis yesterday.
Julia Robertson is still here and talks of going back home 
without teaching.
Tell me all about yourself dear Johnny. I think about 
you all the time, and wonder how you are, if you are 
happy &c&c, and then feel how hard it is to be so 
separated. indeed it is dreadful. I cannot get used 
it nor I never want to. I must love you with all 
my heart as long as I live and if I so love you how can I help wanting 
to see you and be with you. A great deal of love from 
all, more than I can express from your devoted Mother
M L M
Needs Review

to-morrow is washday?, but if I can I may write a 
little more, do you have Carbon, (or rack?), oil in 
Chicago, it comes from Allgheny? is burned in a glass 
lamp that costs 50 cents, and each about one 
cent a night, but care is requisite 
to present its evaporating when not burning.
Pa is trying it and thinks of getting a barrel at 
50 cts a gallon, it is much cheaper than candles

Dearest Johnny Decr 21st
It is in my heart to write you a long letter 
for it is full and would fain pour itself out. My affections 
know no shadow of diminution and my dear absent ones 
receive their full share. What else of earth is worth living for.
But dearie should I write you and long letter. I might perchance 
give it the hue of sadness as that is just now the tinge 
of my own feelings, for Pa is quite sick today, for some 
week we (and he too) thought him improving, but for 
the last two weeks he has not been so well and for a 
few days, worse, last night he has one of his severe coughing 
spells &c. but no hemorge. this morning his throat is 
so sore he can hardly speak or swallow. I have thought 
him looking very badly, worse than ever, for some time 
appetite not very good, he still goes out a little.
We have tried to find an opportunity to send you the 
books you want but, the previous we applied to had 
given up going, those who went we knew nothing 
about. Riall says he will go as soon as he sells 
out. I have just written to Dr Noset? and asked 
him to see Mr. Newsom about that claim.
Mr. Vinton is in Florida just now with Sarah 
but I spoke to him about it once. i do not recollect 
what he said, but he did not seem to think he could do
Needs Review

any more about it than any body else, of the two 
Noret seemed the most willing to have it done 
So I have asked him to let me know about it and 
then you and Mr. Newsom all to agree about it. 
The witnesses are two very old men in Franch 
Grant, either dead or doting by this time as it is 
a year or two ago. I do not know any other way 
than thro' this Mr. N., I am sorry you anticipated such 
a dull Christmas, but I do not know that we shall have 
any menieu? times, Charlotte talks of coming, but I 
shall not urge it, as she is coming so soon to stay 
once the weather generally so inclement at that time 
and she not very well. I am sending you a magasince 
for a Christmas gift. I think it pretty one. 
is the railroad finished all the way to Chicago? 
I have not made up my mind about your going 
to Texas. I do not like Chicago but a tree torn up 
every year will never take root nor thrive, at any 
rate I should not want you to go any for the away 
untill Pa gets better or has a better prospect of doing so. 
I told Charlotte I had a mind to offer your services to 
Mr. Vinton and then you could go for Sarah in the spring.
She is coming via N. Orleans. I thought she might mention 
it to Sarah in the course of their correspondence.
Needs Review

I may go to Gallipolis in the spring and see Mr Vinton 
of course I will not forget you, I am too anxious 
to have you nearer to me.
We are all getting along as usual working, hearing 
lessons, walking &c. Toven? quite as lively as ever 
the railroad, ah yes the railroad, why just as 
it was, but in the church you will think we are 
mayresing?, as we are to have a fine melodeon?! 
I like it better than the organ, it does not so drown 
the singing, which ought to be heard, as it is a part 
of worship. I hope your next letter will be about 
your precious self, as that is the best part of Chicago 
to Me. Since I have heard the soil is so thin I am 
often afraid you will sink. 
Much love from all the Children, the merry and 
happy congratulations of the seasons and an overflowing 
abundance of love from your ever devoted Mother,
M. LeM-
